name: Young Creek
description:
Introduction

Be aware: Young Creek was hit by a spot-burn from the Eagle Creek wildfire in Sept 2017 and was closed for a significant period of time. Please use extreme caution when approaching and descending the creek. The local land managers request that no further bolts be added, but we can replace whatever is currently there.

Young Creek is a drainage located just west of Bridal Veil Creek in the Columbia Gorge. The Historic Columbia River Highway (HCRH) crosses the creek on a beautiful high bridge built in 1915. Signs denote this as “Shepperds Dell". A very short paved trail with a neat stone walkway leads down to the top of one of the waterfalls (R5). However, there are four more falls just upstream and two short drops located underneath the bridge. The bridge is conveniently located for assessing the flow rate on the creek prior to committing to the canyon. The canyon sees substantially higher flow earlier in the season.

  • Beware poison oak, briars, and rockfall on the approach and exit.
  • Use caution when walking along the road; it's narrow and there's little to no shoulder.
  • Watershed: ~2.0mi^2.

Approach

Directions

Take I-84 to exit 28 (Bridal Veil). Turn right on the Old Columbia River Hwy and continue 1.7mi to a signed pullout for Shepperds Dell just before the bridge across Young Creek.

Hike In

  • Original Approach

From the pullout, walk across the bridge and continue west along the road a hundred yards to the next obvious drainage gully coming in on the south side. Break off the road here and thrash upwards about 200ft wherever is easiest. It’s steep, but goes relatively quickly. It's a good idea to wear a helmet on the approach as this area has become rather unstable post-fire; beware knocking loose rocks on one another. Head for an obvious notch above, avoiding thickets of briars and poison oak. Once through the notch, the terrain abruptly mellows out. Follow the flat bench east until you reach the creek, now deeply entrenched below. Looking down from here you should be able to spot the top of R2 where the creek abruptly drops into a narrow slot.

  • Shuttle Approach (unexplored)

It may be possible to shuttle up Alex Barr Road and hike/bushwhack north from the obvious switchback, staying on public land. Eventually, meet the original route and follow it east to the creek. It's about 0.3mi, losing some 600ft of elevation.

Descent

The uppermost falls on Young Creek (12ft high) is located a few hundred yards upstream from the drop-in described above. This falls, however, is on private property, is unimpressive, and requires significant bushwhacking to reach. Not recommended.

  • R1: Rappel 30ft from any convenient tree to enter the drainage. Look for webbing on obvious tree.
  • R2: 90ft into a calf-deep pool from a bolt station along the big wall high DCL. Pull is nice. You can engage flow as much or as little as you’d like. Bolts can be overgrown; found up and to the left of the landing from the obvious tree used for R1.

Below the pool, the creek enters a mossy V-slot with three short drops (3-5ft) in quick succession. There is a nice shelf DCR that can be used to avoid the cluttered V-slot.

  • R3 + traverse: 15ft traverse from a single bolt DCR to another single bolt DCR right on the brink. (Rigged as a rebelay in high water.) From the main anchor, it's 95ft to the bottom. Use caution when deploying the rope as the bottom of this falls occasionally sees visitors climbing up from below. This is the crux. At high flow, be prepared to stem over the torrent and use a narrow / almost unseen ledge DCR. Enter the flow quickly as the force will be very pushy. Be confident in your high water skills for this. The station manager will not be able to see anyone on the rope. Would be wise to use a bottom belay from below. Use caution as there is some rockfall hazard on this pitch.
  • R4: 20ft from a large rock DCR or bypass DCR.

Below R4, downclimb to the railed pedestrian trail atop of R5. Escape is possible via the trail.

  • R5: 60ft from the concrete post at the end of the pedestrian walkway. The bottom of this rappel is the large amphitheater underneath the bridge. When finished, go back and remove your webbing. (Please help us keep the amphitheater clean and pack out any garbage you might find down there. Unfortunately, some idiots think it's okay to throw trash off the bridge.)
  • R6: 20ft from a large rock DCR. A house-sized boulder blocks the exit from the amphitheater. Rappel DCR in the flow, or DCL for out of the water / less water.

01/July/2023 - This rock is unstable and walks some - consider this a marginal anchor. We had last rappeller sit on the rock until all others were safely down; then last member repelled with a soft low start.

A short downclimb exits the narrows. Make your way down the stream to the railroad tracks.

Exit

Walking along the railroad line is trespassing (not to mention trains come barreling through here at 60mph with little to no warning), so stay off the tracks. Keep back in the woods and head west until you reach the next gulley. Climb upwards wherever is easiest (avoiding thickets of bramble and briars) until you reach the wall below the old highway about 100ft above. If you come up in the right spot there’s a nice person-sized opening in the stone guardrail (seemingly designed for canyoneers). Walk back east along the road to the bridge and your car.

Red tape

Please stay on public land during the approach and exit.

Canyoneers will be in full view from the bridge and pedestrian walkway on the last two rappels. Canyoning is still not a well known activity in the Columbia Gorge and it would be good not to linger overly long or overstay your welcome. Please help pack out any trash you should encounter below the bridge and help leave the place cleaner than when you found it. Please do not leave anchors in view of the public to keep the inexperienced / curious from attempting to follow you.

Beta sites

Shepperd's Dell State Natural Area

Creek was first descended by Portland locals in October 2015.
